newsitem.title: USA: Enterprise deregulation clouds going away.
newsitem.headline: Enterprise deregulation clouds going away.

text.p: The clouds of utility deregulation are going away at Public Service Enterprise Group Inc, chief financial officer Robert C. Murray told Reuters.
Noting industry changes "are coming faster than many people thought possible," he said the transition "will cause us some pain. But we're not being gored" like many feared.
Although it is still to early to tell, the read on New Jersey's deregulation proposeals is pretty good, he continued.

The director of state governmental affiars at the company's utility subsidiary, Frederick D. DeSanti, said "I am very pleased with the way the (various) coalitions are coming forward" in support of needed tax changes and securitization of stranded assets during talks on deregulations.
The business community was "very moderate" at last week's initial hearings on the New Jersey Master Energy Plan, he pointed out in an interview.
"We've been through (deregulation) on the (natural) gas side," Murray pointed out, noting the company is the largest natural gas distribution utility east of the Mississippi.
He also said the pressure off a negative debt rating change appears to be off following talks with Standard & Poors and Moody's. Both agencies have the company on watch with negative implications.
Murray said Moody's has said it is not changing Enterprise's ratings, but the negative indicators will not be lifted until the Salem Generating Station comes back on line.
PSE&G, which has a 42.59 percent interest in Salem, has said it expects the plant to be back in operation this summer.
In December, S&P revised the outlook of PECO Energy Co, which has a similar Salem stake, to positive citing a Pennsylavania law allowing securitization of stranded costs.
Securitization has been proposed by New Jersey regulators, but the legislature has taken no action, DeSanti noted.
PSE&G's "real challenge" under deregulation, according to senior vice president Alfred C. Koeppe, is changing the company's culture "to offense from defense."

Stating the company's "strength is our people," he said the stability of the six year contracts PSE&G has reached with its unions means the utility has the potential of finding additional work for its field forces from others in need of quality help. ((-- New York Newsdesk 212-859-1610.))
